awd_titl_txt: Extraction and Transport to the Magnetosphere of Solar Wind Energy during Periods of Low Mach Number Solar Wind Flow
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the impacts of space weather, changes in the magnetic plasma environment surrounding the Earth, relies on basic definitions of how we measure extreme conditions. Geomagnetic storms represent the extremes of our local geospace environment and represent times when our national space-based assets (satellites for defense and commerce) are most vulnerable. This work will determine what conditions lead to extreme space weather through use of observational datasets and physics-based models of the space environment. The broader impacts include understanding space weather conditions during extreme conditions (a priority set out in the National Space Weather Action Plan) and training students and a post-doc on research in a Hispanic Serving Institution.

This project develops a new classification of geomagnetic storms based on overall storm energetics, with an emphasis on storms with large amounts of power dissipated in the ionosphere where the activity can have significant space weather consequences. A set of events will be selected that will represent the most energetic storms, including "superstorms" that occur under conditions of low Mach number solar wind flow. These events will be studied using both data and simulations (global MHD models run with and without a ring current module) to determine the controlling factors for energy transfer to the geospace system. The goal of this research is to create a comprehensive conceptual model that explains how the solar wind energy incident on the magnetosphere is transferred to the ionosphere and magnetosphere during periods of the relatively low solar wind Mach number that characterize large magnetic storms. The research will also identify to what extent current global models can capture the essential physics of that transfer and identify possible areas of missing physics that could contribute to a better correspondence between models and data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit of this  research is that it established that during large magnetic storms, the relationship between the solar wind and the amount of energy transferred to Earth's ionosphere is controlled by the solar wind Mach number.  This is in accord with theoretical studies that provided a physics-based model for understand that energy transfer, which is governed by different rules during smaller geomagnetic disturbances.  Understanding the physics of energy transfer during large geomagnetic storms is very important for space weather prediction.  The research supported by this grant resulted in 6 papers published in peer-reviewed journals, and several conference presentations.  In addition, other researchers in the community, citing our work, have provided additional evidence that the model we propose is correct.

 

The broader impacts of the research grant are that it supported the research of four graduate students.  Three of these (all women and one being African-American) graduated with their PhDs.  Two of them have Postdoctoral positions at NASA, and one is a PostDoc at the University of Michigan.  Four undergraduates received support from this grant to present their research a regional conferences.  One student is now in a space physics PhD program.  In addition, there was a supplement to this grant to support outreach to African-American students at Morgan State University, a HBCU in Baltimore, MD.  Several seminars on the space environment were presented at Morgan State, and the grant paid for 6 students to attend a space physics conference.  One of the students has gone on to a graduate program in Astrophysics, and the others (who have not yet graduated) are considering the possibility of careers in space science.  Therefore, the human resource development supported the grant was extensive.
